Award.AwardTitle: Connections between Advanced and Secondary Mathematics: Exploring the Impact of Abstract Algebra on the Teaching and Learning of Secondary Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This conference project will bring together a diverse group of scholars and practitioners interested in studying the connections between abstract algebra as studied at the university level and the abstract algebra used by teachers in K-12 mathematics. Recent policy documents advocate for including advanced topics such as abstract algebra as a fundamental part of secondary teacher preparation, and a large majority of schools require students to take abstract algebra. Understanding the implications of such a requirement is imperative to improving secondary mathematics education. This conference will gather together people interested in this topic by providing a common space that cuts across communities (e.g., teaching institutions, research institutions, teacher educators), an opportunity not typically offered by established conferences and meetings. Through the dedicated working groups at the conference, all attendees will make progress on research and professional development that will directly contribute to advancing knowledge around the role of connections between advanced and secondary mathematics (particularly abstract algebra) in the preparation of teachers.

The conference will meet three objectives. The first objective will be to share current research on mathematical connections between advanced and secondary mathematics, focusing specifically on abstract algebra. The second objective will be to develop plans for research and/or professional development to expand current knowledge on connections between advanced and school mathematics, so that attendees can take concrete steps to move research forward. The third objective will be to provide a space for mathematicians, mathematics educators, and other stakeholders to discuss their work and develop a common vision for future directions. In particular, opportunities will be provided to look across research and practice, name common goals, and elaborate a trajectory for researching and supporting the needs of secondary school teachers to understand and use abstract algebra in their teaching.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Connecting Advanced and Secondary Mathematics (CASM) conference was held May 20-22, 2019 at the University of Minnesota. The conference, which brought together higher education faculty and graduate students, focused on the connections between undergraduate and K-12 mathematics. The conference had three main objectives: 

  • Share current research on mathematical connections between advanced and secondary mathematics, focusing specifically on abstract algebra, an upper-level course often taken by mathematics and mathematics education majors.  

  • Develop plans for research and/or professional development to expand current knowledge on connections between undergraduate and K-12 mathematics, so that attendees could take concrete steps to move projects forward. 

  • Provide a space for mathematicians, mathematics educators, and other stakeholders to discuss their work and develop a common vision for future directions. 

Travel funding was provided to 47 of the 53 attendees, who came from 36 different institutions. Conference attendees came from a variety of institutions and academic backgrounds. All participants submitted applications to participate detailing how they would use the conference to further their own research and/or teaching practice, and participants were selected to ensure diversity of backgrounds.  Geographically, attendees came from 22 states and 5 countries (United States, Canada, Mexico, New Zealand, Israel).

During the conference, attendees were organized into groups to help them find collaborators, identify potential funding sources, discuss methodological or implementation challenges, refine new research questions, and plan for data collection, analysis, and implementation of projects. Each group pursued one or more of these goals as relevant to them. 

Based on our end of the conference survey, attendees noted personal gains in each of the areas related to our objectives. We asked attendees to rate aspects of the conference using a five-point scale. Attendees rated several features of the conference as very useful including overall structure (4.26 out of 5), informal interaction with other attendees (4.66 out of 5), and small group work (4.36 out of 5). We also asked attendees to report personal gain from the conference using a five-point scale. Attendees noted good gain related to building a sense of community (4.27 out of 5) as well as making progress toward developing a project (4.16 out of 5).  

The majority of respondents mentioned support from the community as being the most beneficial aspect of the conferencer that would help them move forward with their own work. Additionally, respondents mentioned regular check-ins and future conferences as helpful aspects to keep them accountable. Many also specified resources such as funding, materials, and collection of relevant literature as being supportive aspects of the conference. Some also mentioned access to Google Drive or Listserv as being helpful in the future with implementation, particularly the participant contact information and contacts of people willing to provide feedback throughout the year.

By far the majority of participants said that communicating with others through small group discussions and forming collaborations with others in their field was the most useful aspect of the conference. Many mentioned the informal discussions as being useful in allowing for networking. Other useful aspects included getting a clear idea of current research and interacting with other researchers. Participants also benefited from getting feedback and giving feedback to others on their projects.

Since the conference, participants have reported progress in a variety of settings. Several groups that began to collaborate at the conference are continuing to work on data collection and analysis together.  In addition, one participant has enhanced their dissertation proposal based on conversations and work done at the conference and at least three participants have written conference proposals for academic conferences that will be held in 2020.
